        Councils & Activities                                                                                                                                                                                 The NYU Silver School of Social Work student body is active in leadership, advocacy, and community engagement through a wide range of student groups and councils.   Take a look at the mission statements of our current student groups below. You can reach the leadership of any group through the email address listed with the group's description.                                                                                                                                                                                                            School Leadership Opportunities                                                                                                     Student Leadership Council   Social Media Team                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Student Councils                                                                                                                                                                        Doctoral Student Association                        The Doctoral Student Association is an advocacy group for PhD students at the Silver School of Social Work at New York University. We are concerned with the overall well-being of SSSW doctoral students and with their participation in the social, academic and professional life of the school. We function as a unifying body for all SSSW doctoral cohorts. We also collaborate with doctoral students from other academic departments, within and outside of NYU, especially with PhD students at other schools of social work in the region. Towards the accomplishment of these goals, the DSA serves as a liaison among SSSW faculty, university administrators and students.     Email: silver.dsa@nyu.edu                                                      Graduate Student Association                      The Graduate Student Association (GSA) is an elected student organization that acts as a liaison between the students and the administration and faculty of the Silver School of Social Work. The GSA also plans several events for the student body throughout the academic year. GSA invites graduate students to bring feedback about the program, suggest events and come to them for direction and assistance. The GSA also plans several events for the student body throughout the academic year, such as student-to-student forums, student faculty meets, informal networking events for social work students, mentoring programs, coffee workshops, end-of-semester celebrations, career panels, and a graduation party.     Email: silver.gsa@nyu.edu                                                      Undergraduate Student Government Association                      The USGA provides a forum for student participation in the educational program and offers a channel of communication between students, faculty, and administration. The USGA sponsors social activities, social work forums, and special events for undergraduates.     Email: silver.usga@nyu.edu                                                                                                                                                                                        Current Student Groups                                                                                                                                                                        Animal Assisted Therapy in Social Work                        The Animal Assisted Therapy in Social Work group provides a forum for students to discuss and explore the variety of animal assisted interventions in the context of social work - from clinical applications and programs, to evidence based research in the field. Activities will include guest speakers from programs currently incorporating animal assisted therapy (AAT), to peer led discussions of current research regarding efficacy of AAT. In addition, we will hold monthly meetings to facilitate networking and information sharing to raise awareness of local and national lectures, events, and conferences, as well as volunteer opportunities. The group is open to all students.       Email: silver.aatsw@nyu.edu                                                        Chinese Student Support Group                        The Chinese Student Support group is an organization created to help international Chinese students with the transition to NYU and the U.S through community and multicultural exploration. The CSSG holds weekly or bi-weekly support group meet ups for its members and they invite you to inquire for more information.     Email: silver.chinesesupportgroup@nyu.edu                                                      Gerontology Student Collective                        The GSC is dedicated to promoting awareness of the increasing need for social workers in the field of gerontology and advocating for better preparation of students to meet the demographic realities of our aging society. The GSC seeks to accomplish this mission by: encouraging the infusion of aging content and social work competencies in aging in the core curriculum, advocating for opportunities to specialize in gerontology, supporting the recruitment and retention of faculty experts in aging, developing and maintaining geriatric field learning placements, and advocating for financial incentives and scholarships for students to concentrate in aging.       E-mail: silver.gsc@nyu.edu                                                        Latino Social Work Student Organization                      The Latino Social Work Student Organization provides support and guidance to Latino students attending NYU Silver School of Social Work. The Latino Social Work Student Organization helps students deepen their understanding of health and social welfare issues facing the Latino community within NYC, broader United States and globally. Our focus is to provide students and the NYU Silver School of Social Work community with greater opportunities to increase cultural competency and effectiveness in providing services to this diverse and multifaceted community.     Email: silver.lswso@nyu.edu                                                      Phi Alpha National Honor Society - Pi Pi Chapter                      Phi Alpha National Honor Society est. 1964 recognizes students in social work for their achievements in academia. The Pi Pi chapter at NYU est. 2009 invites into membership those students who demonstrate academic excellence, as well as those who are committed to providing community service throughout the year. All applicants must complete 9 units in social work courses at the time of application. Graduate students are required to possess a 3.9 GPA, while undergraduate students must possess a 3.5 cumulative and a GPA of 3.75 in all social work courses.     Email: silver.phialpha@nyu.edu   Website: http://phialpha2013.wordpress.com/                                                      Pride in Practice                      Pride and Practice is the student group for bisexual, gay, lesbian, and transgender students in the Silver School of Social Work at NYU. Pride and Practice works to provide emotional support in a safe environment for lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender persons at the Silver School of Social Work regardless of race, ethnicity, or political viewpoint. Pride and Practice is also committed to educating both the Silver School of Social Work community and the community at large about the issues that are important to lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender people.     Email: silver.prideinpractice@nyu.edu                                                      Silver Atheists, Agnostics, and Secular Humanists                        Silver Atheists, Agnostics, and Secular Humanists (SAASH) was organized to create a safe and engaging space for students at the Silver School of Social Work who identify as atheist, agnostic, and/or Secular Humanist. SAASH seeks to develop an atmosphere of mutual aid and support among members and, at the same time, promote discussion on how our professional values as social workers are often connected to our positive moral and ethical values as non-theists and humanists. SAASH is also committed to exploring the ways in which the social, political, and historical foundations of the social work profession were, in many ways, influenced by humanist and non-theistic thinking, and how modern practitioners can revisit and reclaim the secular legacy of social work. Finally, SAASH wishes to promote dialogue between social work students and practitioners who identify as atheist, agnostic, and/or Secular Humanist, those who identify as religious or theist, and those who aren’t sure where they stand, in hopes of enriching the intellectual and academic environment here at Silver.     Email: silver.saash@nyu.edu                                                        Students of Color Collective                        The Students of Color Collective (SOCC) works to provide a safe space for self-identified students of color at the Silver School to come together for peer support. SOCC also works with the larger School to create programming and educational opportunities related to racial diversity issues.     Email: silver.socc@nyu.edu   SOCC Blog                                                      Student Collective for Global Social Work                      The NYU Student Collective for Global Social Work (SCGSW) is committed to working with vulnerable populations to address issues affecting the health, well-being and human rights of our global community.   Group Objectives:     Generate dialogue about the international roles of social work in clinical, policy, and advocacy capacities   Advocate for ethical and culturally-competent practices and policies worldwide   Share information about events, conferences and workshops as well as volunteer and job opportunities that pertain to human rights and international social welfare   Expand students' knowledge of the various career paths in international social work by bringing professionals from the field.   Work in collaboration with faculty in advancing their agenda of an international social work focus   Serve as a voice in the community in establishing a social worker's perspective in human rights and social justice issues on an international level       Email: silver.scgsw@nyu.edu                                                                                            New Student Groups                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Feminists of Silver                      The Feminists of Silver's goals are to create a community for feminist social workers and give a voice to those social workers dedicated to helping women and female-identified individuals.     Email: silver.feminists@nyu.edu                                                       Student Collective for Faith-Driven Social Work Practice                      The Student Collective for Faith-Driven Social Work Practice (SCFSWP) is a socially minded group of students interested in the role of Christianity in Faith-based social work practice. SCFSWP is committed to the development of well informed social work practices as related to faith and/or religious needs and services of vulnerable populations and the broader community. The mission will be fulfilled through expert led information sessions, peer to peer talks and community outreach.     Email: silver.scfswp@nyu.edu                                                       Knock Knock Give A Sock                      Knock Knock Give A Sock is college started initiative dedicated to collecting socks for those in need and getting communities to work together to help those experiencing homelessness.   This organization seeks to engage college students and have them think of creative ways to work together and meet new students on campus to collect socks for those in need.     Email: silver.knockknock@nyu.edu                                                                                            Inactive Student Groups                                                                                                   If you would like to take on the leadership of one of these groups, please reach out to silver.studentaffairs@nyu.edu . We'll help get you and the group going.                                                                                                                                                                      NextSteppers                      The Next Steppers - Silver Non-Traditional Students Association is an organization that supports the needs of students who are changing careers and/or returning to school after several years. Activities will include social events as well as monthly group discussions about topics of interest such as: financial aid, new technologies, using what you've learned at work to succeed as a student, how your current skill set translates to social work, balancing family and schoolwork, and much more. In addition, we will pool our unique skills and talents in service to all our fellow students as well as the wider community through volunteer activities and workshops. All students are welcome to join.     Email: silver.ntsa@nyu.edu                                                      Social Workers on Public Policy                      Social Workers on Public Policy (SWOPP) works to empower and educate social workers on issues within local, state, and federal government as it relates to the NASW Code of Ethics. SWOPP works to engage social workers and disadvantaged communities through educational events and community activism that reflects issues of the current political climate. SWOPP offers discussion groups, lectures, distributes literature on voter registration and promotes empowerment through political action and awareness.     Email: silver.swopp@nyu.edu                                                      U+ME                        Unity through Multicultural Education (U+ME) is a student group which seeks to educate, question, and challenge each other on topics surrounding diversity and social justice as they relate to the Silver School of Social Work and the social work field at large. U+ME offers critical discussions groups, workshops, movie nights, and other events at the Silver School of Social Work.     Email: silver.uandme@nyu.edu                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       Create a New Student Group   If you want to get involved and cannot find a group that matches your interest, start your own! Contact ssw.studentaffairs@nyu.edu and visit the Student Group Recognition Page for more information. SAASH is also committed to exploring the ways in which the social, political, and historical foundations of the social work profession were, in many ways, influenced by humanist and non-theistic thinking, and how modern practitioners can revisit and reclaim the secular legacy of social work. Finally, SAASH wishes to promote dialogue between social work students and practitioners who identify as atheist, agnostic, and/or Secular Humanist, those who identify as religious or theist, and those who aren’t sure where they stand, in hopes of enriching the intellectual and academic environment here at Silver.     Email: silver.saash@nyu.edu                                                        Students of Color Collective                        The Students of Color Collective (SOCC) works to provide a safe space for self-identified students of color at the Silver School to come together for peer support. SOCC also works with the larger School to create programming and educational opportunities related to racial diversity issues.     Email: silver.socc@nyu.edu   SOCC Blog                                                      Student Collective for Global Social Work                      The NYU Student Collective for Global Social Work (SCGSW) is committed to working with vulnerable populations to address issues affecting the health, well-being and human rights of our global community.   Group Objectives:     Generate dialogue about the international roles of social work in clinical, policy, and advocacy capacities   Advocate for ethical and culturally-competent practices and policies worldwide   Share information about events, conferences and workshops as well as volunteer and job opportunities that pertain to human rights and international social welfare   Expand students' knowledge of the various career paths in international social work by bringing professionals from the field.   Work in collaboration with faculty in advancing their agenda of an international social work focus   Serve as a voice in the community in establishing a social worker's perspective in human rights and social justice issues on an international level       Email: silver.scgsw@nyu.edu                                                                                            New Student Groups                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Feminists of Silver                      The Feminists of Silver's goals are to create a community for feminist social workers and give a voice to those social workers dedicated to helping women and female-identified individuals.     Email: silver.feminists@nyu.edu                                                       Student Collective for Faith-Driven Social Work Practice                      The Student Collective for Faith-Driven Social Work Practice (SCFSWP) is a socially minded group of students interested in the role of Christianity in Faith-based social work practice. SCFSWP is committed to the development of well informed social work practices as related to faith and/or religious needs and services of vulnerable populations and the broader community. The mission will be fulfilled through expert led information sessions, peer to peer talks and community outreach.     Email: silver.scfswp@nyu.edu                                                       Knock Knock Give A Sock                      Knock Knock Give A Sock is college started initiative dedicated to collecting socks for those in need and getting communities to work together to help those experiencing homelessness. NextSteppers                      The Next Steppers - Silver Non-Traditional Students Association is an organization that supports the needs of students who are changing careers and/or returning to school after several years. Activities will include social events as well as monthly group discussions about topics of interest such as: financial aid, new technologies, using what you've learned at work to succeed as a student, how your current skill set translates to social work, balancing family and schoolwork, and much more. In addition, we will pool our unique skills and talents in service to all our fellow students as well as the wider community through volunteer activities and workshops. SWOPP offers discussion groups, lectures, distributes literature on voter registration and promotes empowerment through political action and awareness. Working Groups | English | NYU                                               Back to Home           Printer Friendly                     Working Groups      1. Transnational Everyday Life     This research group on ‘everyday life’ intends to refocus on the material and cultural dimensions of the everyday. A crucial impulse behind this project is to de-mystify an obsessive focus on extraordinary events of violence and catastrophe in a global context. While exploring everyday life in the Euro-American context, a considerable part of the project will be devoted to the study of everyday life in the Muslim world.      Contact information: Mosarrap Hossain Khan           2. Archival Practice Workshop     During the 2013-2014 school year, the Workshop in Archival Practice will be exploring the intersections between book history, broadly defined, and the archive. As in many other fields, the contribution of archival research to scholarship in the history of the book is not often discussed, and we hope to generate interesting questions and avenues for research through our readings and conversations. Below are the questions that form the basis of this inquiry and that can and likely will change as we explore the topic in more depth:         What does interesting and excellent book history look like? How is archival research integrated into this work?   What can we learn from this work that can be applied in our own?   How do we, as scholars interested in the book history and/or archives, make responsible use of previous research done in these field in our own work (which may or may not necessarily be related)?   What are the archives of book history? Where are they located (perhaps with a specific focus on finding/visiting collections in New York City)?   What are ways in which scholarship, whether our own or that of others, effectively connects these two fields with a larger concept of media history?        Faculty advisors for 2013–14: Lisa Gitelman , Liz McHenry    Contact information: Rob Koehler , Laura Yoder           3. Digital Experiments     Digital Experiments is a graduate-faculty working group in the Department of English at New York University. Our group explores and develops tools for digital research in the humanities. The group pursues a broad understanding of the intersection between digital tools and humanistic inquiry by engaging in collaborative practices of research, writing, and discussion. Taking a cue from Samuel Johnson’s definition of “experiment”—“The Trial of anything; something done in order to discover an uncertain or unknown effect”—we view our work as an investigation into how digital tools and practices can reshape  literary studies today.     Our work is driven as much by process as by product. While members of the group have varied research interests—ranging from early modern knowledge systems to contemporary social media platforms—we share and foster investigative practices that query the division between making and critiquing. As we acquire new skills in digital textual analysis, we reflect on the conceptual underpinnings of these methods. To this end, we have adopted a variety of reflexive critical strategies for our meetings, including the “charette model” of production, which entails short-term solutions to long-term conceptual and methodological problems.      Faculty advisors for 2013–14: Bill Blake , David Hoover    Contact information: Collin Jennings , Rachael King , Rob Koehler , Laura Yoder           4. Modern and Contemporary Culture (MACC)     The “Modern and Contemporary Colloquium (MACC)” will continue to provide a forum for students and faculty whose intellectual interests converge on modern and contemporary topics, social movements, and cultural products. Given the flexibility of its frame, MACC aims to foster conversations that cut across cultural, linguistic, national and geographic specializations, as well as period and disciplinary divisions. To this effect, MACC will organize presentations, round tables, and discussion groups that explore a range of topics pertaining to modernization, modernisms, (post)modernity, and contemporary literatures and cultures. In general, our sessions will fall into the following categories:         Discussions of key texts in modern literature, culture, and theory   Panel presentations by MA and Doctoral students' work with faculty and student respondents (possibly organized as a conference).   Presentations and discussion of longer papers by graduate students, NYU faculty, and visiting speakers.       In the 2012-13 academic year, MACC plans to organize its events around a general theme, though sessions will remain open to refashioning and redirection—or, to the particular, timely needs and interests of our intellectual community. The upcoming year's theme will be “Memory Strategies.”      Faculty advisors for 2013–14: Peter Nicholls , Patrick Deer    Contact information: David Hobbs , Caitlin Hurst           5. NewYorkScapes     NewYorkScapes is dedicated to exploring the textual productions that emerge from and are based in New York City along with their relationships to local, national, and global cultures and spaces. Part of a Humanities Initiative working group and departmental Digital Commons project, NYScapes focuses on combining the methods and concepts of the spatial humanities, a developing branch of the digital humanities, with traditional literary inquiry. Applying the analytical tools of geographic information systems (GIS) technology—the driving force behind the spatial humanities—will enable the group to examine links between literary New York and its physical and imaginative streets and structures, offering exciting insights into the spatial and temporal dimensions of cultural materials.      Faculty advisors: Thomas Augst , Peter Wosh    Contact information: Kristen Doyle Highland , Blevin Shelnutt           6. Done Dissertation     “The Done Dissertation: A Forum for Writers” is intended to provide a public forum for every dissertation writer. A student who has recently defended will present a section of the completed project and field questions from the NYU community. In addition to recognizing a successful defense and completion of the PhD, the forum recognizes students who are in the midst of writing because it provides them with an opportunity to learn from colleagues as well as to voice their own experiences as writers. The English department event space at Greene St. would be the preferred venue. These events will  be held shortly after a student defends. We plan to schedule our first event in early September.      Contact information: Bridget McFarland , Veronica Goosey           7. Pope and/in Media     We are planning to hold an event focusing on the work of Alexander Pope, his poetics, his politics, his peers, and the media ecology of the eighteenth century. This event will combine elements of a conference and a workshop, emphasizing collaborative work before, during and after the meeting. Late spring or early fall 2014 at NYU (exact building TBD).      Contact information: Pat Abatiell , Rob Koehler , Laura Yoder           8. Pun Pilgrimage     This is a one-off evening event, scheduled as October's First Wednesday event (October 2, 7 pm, 300 Silver Center), followed by a reception in the Event Space at 244 Greene Street. Introduced by Jo Livingstone (Graduate Student, NYU English Department) and presented in conjunction with NYU Professor John Archer's undergraduate Shakespeare course, London-based performance artist Hannah Catherine Jones, aka Foxy Moron, asks: What does it mean to perform a pun? To become a pun? This interdisciplinary event explores the art and science of the pun as a marriage of language and action through a performative artist talk, including selected works from Jones' repertoire and a question and answer session. For more, see: http://www.washingtonsquareartsclub.com      Contact information: Josephine Livingstone , Laura Yoder           9. Post-colonial     The Postcolonial Seminar provides a forum for the discussion of current issues in postcolonial theory by inviting prominent figures in the field to discuss their recent work. In addition to providing a means for students and faculty in the English department to further pursue interests in postcolonial studies beyond the classroom, the Postcolonial Seminar also serves as a vital forum to create dialogues between other departments and institutions.      Contact information: Rajiv Menon (away Fall 2013), Adam Spanos           10. Romanticist Research Group     Group organizers will be presenting in the Art and Scholarship special session of the M/MLA Conference (Nov. 2013) on last year’s event, the production of the staged reading of Sardanapalus and its implications for literary scholarship. This presentation will be followed by a co-produced staged reading of Percy Shelley’s Prometheus Unbound with Red Bull Theater, scheduled for November 18, 2013. In addition to maintaining our blog (nyurrg.org), we will make use of new digital opportunities to document our experience through video interviews with directors and other Red Bull affiliates. The organizers will be be using both performances as case studies for a collaborative article.      Group co-ordinators for the event 2013–14: Omar F. Miranda , Veronica Goosey , Randall Sessler           11. Medieval Forum     The Medieval Forum is an arena in which faculty and graduate students from the New York metropolitan area can engage in the lively exchange of a thriving center of medieval scholarship. We intend to host one public event each semester, likely in conjunction with the Medieval and Renaissance Center, and meet once or twice a semester for an informal reading group to practice reading aloud (specifically not translating) medieval languages, especially Old, Early Middle, and Late Middle English. We anticipate inviting a medieval professor from NYU and/or from the New York metropolitan area to participate in the reading group and then ending with a dinner, to which all attendees would be invited. We have already begun planning the 3rd Annual Medieval Manuscripts Workshop with Martha Rust for the Fall (late September and early October).      Faculty advisors: Hal Momma , Martha Rust    Contact information: Angie Bennett Segler , Carla María Thomas           12. Organism for Poetic Research (OCR)     The Organism for Poetic Research (OPR) organizes and initiates events that open a collaborative field for experimentation and research performed in the humanities, the natural sciences, the visual arts and poetry. The OPR produces the annual magazine PELT (available in distinct manifestations in print and on the web) which features work by artists and academics connected with OPR activities and events. The OPR website advertises calls for work and OPR events, publishes proceedings from events (in the form of text, image, audio, and video files), hosts web residencies held by artists and academics, and publishes webPELT, an online magazine that reproduces materials from the printed PELT (thereby allowing it a wider circulation) and contributes materials better suited to a digital medium.      Faculty advisors for 2013–14: Lytle Shaw , Una Chaudhuri    Contact information: Rachael Wilson , Ada Smailbegovic           13. Politics of the Contemporary Novel Reading Group     This group focuses on the politics of the contemporary novel, particularly in relation to "global" paradigms of literary and critical practice. We ask what the novel does to organize narrative worlds, as well as how it might be said to critique or re-imagine existing frameworks for understanding the political realities of the contemporary moment. In doing so, we also address the dynamics by which novels circulate throughout the globe, and seek to interrogate and expand current critical methods for reading this complex set of literary phenomena.     Our group, then, also seeks to ask questions of the discipline itself - to dig deeper into some of the commonplaces of our practice and to refine our understanding of the political potentialities of both literature and literary criticism. We ask, for instance, what might it really mean for a novel to act politically? In what ways can it be said that the novel intervenes in politics? And how can critique itself function best as a political practice in the contemporary moment? We will select readings according to group interest, but in general each meeting will pair a work of contemporary fiction with relevant selections from recent scholarly work.      Contact information: Pat Abatiell           14. The Victorian Reading Group     We will ruminate over primary texts (both fictional and non-fictional) written in the post-Romantic 19th century. We will concern ourselves with readings that deal with the prominent social issues of the Victorian era: the ‘woman question’ (marriage, suffrage, bodily autonomy, etc.), industrialization and its effects (slums, the urban poor, changed conditions of labour, etc.), colony and Empire. As opposed to focusing solely on long novels and poetry—as is often the temptation with Victorian literature—the group will read shorter texts that were widely distributed and widely read at the time of publication, with a particular focus on the short story as an emergent literary genre. We will read works that appeared in publications such as Household Words, Blackwoods, The Morning Chronicle, and Graham’s Magazine , among others. We will, in other words, look to the popular instead of exclusively the canonical and examine how contemporary texts reflected and shaped the dialogue around the issues of the day.         Councils & Activities                                                                                                                                                                                 The NYU Silver School of Social Work student body is active in leadership, advocacy, and community engagement through a wide range of student groups and councils.   Take a look at the mission statements of our current student groups below. You can reach the leadership of any group through the email address listed with the group's description.                                                                                                                                                                                                            School Leadership Opportunities                                                                                                     Student Leadership Council   Social Media Team                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Student Councils                                                                                                                                                                        Doctoral Student Association                        The Doctoral Student Association is an advocacy group for PhD students at the Silver School of Social Work at New York University. We are concerned with the overall well-being of SSSW doctoral students and with their participation in the social, academic and professional life of the school. We function as a unifying body for all SSSW doctoral cohorts. We also collaborate with doctoral students from other academic departments, within and outside of NYU, especially with PhD students at other schools of social work in the region. Towards the accomplishment of these goals, the DSA serves as a liaison among SSSW faculty, university administrators and students.     Email: silver.dsa@nyu.edu                                                      Graduate Student Association                      The Graduate Student Association (GSA) is an elected student organization that acts as a liaison between the students and the administration and faculty of the Silver School of Social Work. The GSA also plans several events for the student body throughout the academic year. GSA invites graduate students to bring feedback about the program, suggest events and come to them for direction and assistance. The GSA also plans several events for the student body throughout the academic year, such as student-to-student forums, student faculty meets, informal networking events for social work students, mentoring programs, coffee workshops, end-of-semester celebrations, career panels, and a graduation party.     Email: silver.gsa@nyu.edu                                                      Undergraduate Student Government Association                      The USGA provides a forum for student participation in the educational program and offers a channel of communication between students, faculty, and administration. The USGA sponsors social activities, social work forums, and special events for undergraduates.     Email: silver.usga@nyu.edu                                                                                                                                                                                        Current Student Groups                                                                                                                                                                        Animal Assisted Therapy in Social Work                        The Animal Assisted Therapy in Social Work group provides a forum for students to discuss and explore the variety of animal assisted interventions in the context of social work - from clinical applications and programs, to evidence based research in the field. Activities will include guest speakers from programs currently incorporating animal assisted therapy (AAT), to peer led discussions of current research regarding efficacy of AAT. In addition, we will hold monthly meetings to facilitate networking and information sharing to raise awareness of local and national lectures, events, and conferences, as well as volunteer opportunities. The group is open to all students.       Email: silver.aatsw@nyu.edu                                                        Chinese Student Support Group                        The Chinese Student Support group is an organization created to help international Chinese students with the transition to NYU and the U.S through community and multicultural exploration. The CSSG holds weekly or bi-weekly support group meet ups for its members and they invite you to inquire for more information.     Email: silver.chinesesupportgroup@nyu.edu                                                      Gerontology Student Collective                        The GSC is dedicated to promoting awareness of the increasing need for social workers in the field of gerontology and advocating for better preparation of students to meet the demographic realities of our aging society. The GSC seeks to accomplish this mission by: encouraging the infusion of aging content and social work competencies in aging in the core curriculum, advocating for opportunities to specialize in gerontology, supporting the recruitment and retention of faculty experts in aging, developing and maintaining geriatric field learning placements, and advocating for financial incentives and scholarships for students to concentrate in aging.       E-mail: silver.gsc@nyu.edu                                                        Latino Social Work Student Organization                      The Latino Social Work Student Organization provides support and guidance to Latino students attending NYU Silver School of Social Work. The Latino Social Work Student Organization helps students deepen their understanding of health and social welfare issues facing the Latino community within NYC, broader United States and globally. Our focus is to provide students and the NYU Silver School of Social Work community with greater opportunities to increase cultural competency and effectiveness in providing services to this diverse and multifaceted community.     Email: silver.lswso@nyu.edu                                                      Phi Alpha National Honor Society - Pi Pi Chapter                      Phi Alpha National Honor Society est. 1964 recognizes students in social work for their achievements in academia. The Pi Pi chapter at NYU est. 2009 invites into membership those students who demonstrate academic excellence, as well as those who are committed to providing community service throughout the year. All applicants must complete 9 units in social work courses at the time of application. Graduate students are required to possess a 3.9 GPA, while undergraduate students must possess a 3.5 cumulative and a GPA of 3.75 in all social work courses. Pride and Practice is also committed to educating both the Silver School of Social Work community and the community at large about the issues that are important to lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender people. Email: silver.socc@nyu.edu   SOCC Blog                                                      Student Collective for Global Social Work                      The NYU Student Collective for Global Social Work (SCGSW) is committed to working with vulnerable populations to address issues affecting the health, well-being and human rights of our global community.   Group Objectives:     Generate dialogue about the international roles of social work in clinical, policy, and advocacy capacities   Advocate for ethical and culturally-competent practices and policies worldwide   Share information about events, conferences and workshops as well as volunteer and job opportunities that pertain to human rights and international social welfare   Expand students' knowledge of the various career paths in international social work by bringing professionals from the field.   Work in collaboration with faculty in advancing their agenda of an international social work focus   Serve as a voice in the community in establishing a social worker's perspective in human rights and social justice issues on an international level       Email: silver.scgsw@nyu.edu                                                                                            New Student Groups                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Feminists of Silver                      The Feminists of Silver's goals are to create a community for feminist social workers and give a voice to those social workers dedicated to helping women and female-identified individuals.     Email: silver.feminists@nyu.edu                                                       Student Collective for Faith-Driven Social Work Practice                      The Student Collective for Faith-Driven Social Work Practice (SCFSWP) is a socially minded group of students interested in the role of Christianity in Faith-based social work practice. SCFSWP is committed to the development of well informed social work practices as related to faith and/or religious needs and services of vulnerable populations and the broader community. The mission will be fulfilled through expert led information sessions, peer to peer talks and community outreach.     Email: silver.scfswp@nyu.edu                                                       Knock Knock Give A Sock                      Knock Knock Give A Sock is college started initiative dedicated to collecting socks for those in need and getting communities to work together to help those experiencing homelessness.   This organization seeks to engage college students and have them think of creative ways to work together and meet new students on campus to collect socks for those in need.     Email: silver.knockknock@nyu.edu                                                                                            Inactive Student Groups                                                                                                   If you would like to take on the leadership of one of these groups, please reach out to silver.studentaffairs@nyu.edu . NextSteppers                      The Next Steppers - Silver Non-Traditional Students Association is an organization that supports the needs of students who are changing careers and/or returning to school after several years. Activities will include social events as well as monthly group discussions about topics of interest such as: financial aid, new technologies, using what you've learned at work to succeed as a student, how your current skill set translates to social work, balancing family and schoolwork, and much more. In addition, we will pool our unique skills and talents in service to all our fellow students as well as the wider community through volunteer activities and workshops. All students are welcome to join. SWOPP works to engage social workers and disadvantaged communities through educational events and community activism that reflects issues of the current political climate. SWOPP offers discussion groups, lectures, distributes literature on voter registration and promotes empowerment through political action and awareness.     Email: silver.swopp@nyu.edu                                                      U+ME                        Unity through Multicultural Education (U+ME) is a student group which seeks to educate, question, and challenge each other on topics surrounding diversity and social justice as they relate to the Silver School of Social Work and the social work field at large. U+ME offers critical discussions groups, workshops, movie nights, and other events at the Silver School of Social Work. Working Groups | English | NYU                                               Back to Home           Printer Friendly                     Working Groups      1. Transnational Everyday Life     This research group on ‘everyday life’ intends to refocus on the material and cultural dimensions of the everyday. A crucial impulse behind this project is to de-mystify an obsessive focus on extraordinary events of violence and catastrophe in a global context. While exploring everyday life in the Euro-American context, a considerable part of the project will be devoted to the study of everyday life in the Muslim world.      Contact information: Mosarrap Hossain Khan           2. Archival Practice Workshop     During the 2013-2014 school year, the Workshop in Archival Practice will be exploring the intersections between book history, broadly defined, and the archive. As in many other fields, the contribution of archival research to scholarship in the history of the book is not often discussed, and we hope to generate interesting questions and avenues for research through our readings and conversations. Below are the questions that form the basis of this inquiry and that can and likely will change as we explore the topic in more depth:         What does interesting and excellent book history look like? How is archival research integrated into this work?   What can we learn from this work that can be applied in our own?   How do we, as scholars interested in the book history and/or archives, make responsible use of previous research done in these field in our own work (which may or may not necessarily be related)?   What are the archives of book history? Where are they located (perhaps with a specific focus on finding/visiting collections in New York City)?   What are ways in which scholarship, whether our own or that of others, effectively connects these two fields with a larger concept of media history?        Faculty advisors for 2013–14: Lisa Gitelman , Liz McHenry    Contact information: Rob Koehler , Laura Yoder           3. Digital Experiments     Digital Experiments is a graduate-faculty working group in the Department of English at New York University. Our group explores and develops tools for digital research in the humanities. The group pursues a broad understanding of the intersection between digital tools and humanistic inquiry by engaging in collaborative practices of research, writing, and discussion. Taking a cue from Samuel Johnson’s definition of “experiment”—“The Trial of anything; something done in order to discover an uncertain or unknown effect”—we view our work as an investigation into how digital tools and practices can reshape  literary studies today.     Our work is driven as much by process as by product. While members of the group have varied research interests—ranging from early modern knowledge systems to contemporary social media platforms—we share and foster investigative practices that query the division between making and critiquing. As we acquire new skills in digital textual analysis, we reflect on the conceptual underpinnings of these methods. To this end, we have adopted a variety of reflexive critical strategies for our meetings, including the “charette model” of production, which entails short-term solutions to long-term conceptual and methodological problems.      Faculty advisors for 2013–14: Bill Blake , David Hoover    Contact information: Collin Jennings , Rachael King , Rob Koehler , Laura Yoder           4. Modern and Contemporary Culture (MACC)     The “Modern and Contemporary Colloquium (MACC)” will continue to provide a forum for students and faculty whose intellectual interests converge on modern and contemporary topics, social movements, and cultural products. Given the flexibility of its frame, MACC aims to foster conversations that cut across cultural, linguistic, national and geographic specializations, as well as period and disciplinary divisions. To this effect, MACC will organize presentations, round tables, and discussion groups that explore a range of topics pertaining to modernization, modernisms, (post)modernity, and contemporary literatures and cultures. In general, our sessions will fall into the following categories:         Discussions of key texts in modern literature, culture, and theory   Panel presentations by MA and Doctoral students' work with faculty and student respondents (possibly organized as a conference).   Presentations and discussion of longer papers by graduate students, NYU faculty, and visiting speakers.       In the 2012-13 academic year, MACC plans to organize its events around a general theme, though sessions will remain open to refashioning and redirection—or, to the particular, timely needs and interests of our intellectual community. The upcoming year's theme will be “Memory Strategies.”      Faculty advisors for 2013–14: Peter Nicholls , Patrick Deer    Contact information: David Hobbs , Caitlin Hurst           5. NewYorkScapes     NewYorkScapes is dedicated to exploring the textual productions that emerge from and are based in New York City along with their relationships to local, national, and global cultures and spaces. Part of a Humanities Initiative working group and departmental Digital Commons project, NYScapes focuses on combining the methods and concepts of the spatial humanities, a developing branch of the digital humanities, with traditional literary inquiry. Applying the analytical tools of geographic information systems (GIS) technology—the driving force behind the spatial humanities—will enable the group to examine links between literary New York and its physical and imaginative streets and structures, offering exciting insights into the spatial and temporal dimensions of cultural materials.      Faculty advisors: Thomas Augst , Peter Wosh    Contact information: Kristen Doyle Highland , Blevin Shelnutt           6. Done Dissertation     “The Done Dissertation: A Forum for Writers” is intended to provide a public forum for every dissertation writer. A student who has recently defended will present a section of the completed project and field questions from the NYU community. In addition to recognizing a successful defense and completion of the PhD, the forum recognizes students who are in the midst of writing because it provides them with an opportunity to learn from colleagues as well as to voice their own experiences as writers. The English department event space at Greene St. would be the preferred venue. These events will  be held shortly after a student defends. We plan to schedule our first event in early September.      Contact information: Bridget McFarland , Veronica Goosey           7. Pope and/in Media     We are planning to hold an event focusing on the work of Alexander Pope, his poetics, his politics, his peers, and the media ecology of the eighteenth century. This event will combine elements of a conference and a workshop, emphasizing collaborative work before, during and after the meeting. Late spring or early fall 2014 at NYU (exact building TBD).      Contact information: Pat Abatiell , Rob Koehler , Laura Yoder           8. Pun Pilgrimage     This is a one-off evening event, scheduled as October's First Wednesday event (October 2, 7 pm, 300 Silver Center), followed by a reception in the Event Space at 244 Greene Street. Introduced by Jo Livingstone (Graduate Student, NYU English Department) and presented in conjunction with NYU Professor John Archer's undergraduate Shakespeare course, London-based performance artist Hannah Catherine Jones, aka Foxy Moron, asks: What does it mean to perform a pun? To become a pun? This interdisciplinary event explores the art and science of the pun as a marriage of language and action through a performative artist talk, including selected works from Jones' repertoire and a question and answer session. For more, see: http://www.washingtonsquareartsclub.com      Contact information: Josephine Livingstone , Laura Yoder           9. Post-colonial     The Postcolonial Seminar provides a forum for the discussion of current issues in postcolonial theory by inviting prominent figures in the field to discuss their recent work. In addition to providing a means for students and faculty in the English department to further pursue interests in postcolonial studies beyond the classroom, the Postcolonial Seminar also serves as a vital forum to create dialogues between other departments and institutions.      Contact information: Rajiv Menon (away Fall 2013), Adam Spanos           10. Romanticist Research Group     Group organizers will be presenting in the Art and Scholarship special session of the M/MLA Conference (Nov. 2013) on last year’s event, the production of the staged reading of Sardanapalus and its implications for literary scholarship. This presentation will be followed by a co-produced staged reading of Percy Shelley’s Prometheus Unbound with Red Bull Theater, scheduled for November 18, 2013. In addition to maintaining our blog (nyurrg.org), we will make use of new digital opportunities to document our experience through video interviews with directors and other Red Bull affiliates. The organizers will be be using both performances as case studies for a collaborative article.      Group co-ordinators for the event 2013–14: Omar F. Miranda , Veronica Goosey , Randall Sessler           11. Medieval Forum     The Medieval Forum is an arena in which faculty and graduate students from the New York metropolitan area can engage in the lively exchange of a thriving center of medieval scholarship. We intend to host one public event each semester, likely in conjunction with the Medieval and Renaissance Center, and meet once or twice a semester for an informal reading group to practice reading aloud (specifically not translating) medieval languages, especially Old, Early Middle, and Late Middle English. We anticipate inviting a medieval professor from NYU and/or from the New York metropolitan area to participate in the reading group and then ending with a dinner, to which all attendees would be invited. We have already begun planning the 3rd Annual Medieval Manuscripts Workshop with Martha Rust for the Fall (late September and early October).      Faculty advisors: Hal Momma , Martha Rust    Contact information: Angie Bennett Segler , Carla María Thomas           12. Organism for Poetic Research (OCR)     The Organism for Poetic Research (OPR) organizes and initiates events that open a collaborative field for experimentation and research performed in the humanities, the natural sciences, the visual arts and poetry. The OPR produces the annual magazine PELT (available in distinct manifestations in print and on the web) which features work by artists and academics connected with OPR activities and events. The OPR website advertises calls for work and OPR events, publishes proceedings from events (in the form of text, image, audio, and video files), hosts web residencies held by artists and academics, and publishes webPELT, an online magazine that reproduces materials from the printed PELT (thereby allowing it a wider circulation) and contributes materials better suited to a digital medium.      Faculty advisors for 2013–14: Lytle Shaw , Una Chaudhuri    Contact information: Rachael Wilson , Ada Smailbegovic           13. Politics of the Contemporary Novel Reading Group     This group focuses on the politics of the contemporary novel, particularly in relation to "global" paradigms of literary and critical practice. We ask what the novel does to organize narrative worlds, as well as how it might be said to critique or re-imagine existing frameworks for understanding the political realities of the contemporary moment. In doing so, we also address the dynamics by which novels circulate throughout the globe, and seek to interrogate and expand current critical methods for reading this complex set of literary phenomena.     Our group, then, also seeks to ask questions of the discipline itself - to dig deeper into some of the commonplaces of our practice and to refine our understanding of the political potentialities of both literature and literary criticism. We ask, for instance, what might it really mean for a novel to act politically? In what ways can it be said that the novel intervenes in politics? And how can critique itself function best as a political practice in the contemporary moment? We will select readings according to group interest, but in general each meeting will pair a work of contemporary fiction with relevant selections from recent scholarly work.      Contact information: Pat Abatiell           14. The Victorian Reading Group     We will ruminate over primary texts (both fictional and non-fictional) written in the post-Romantic 19th century. We will concern ourselves with readings that deal with the prominent social issues of the Victorian era: the ‘woman question’ (marriage, suffrage, bodily autonomy, etc.), industrialization and its effects (slums, the urban poor, changed conditions of labour, etc.), colony and Empire. As opposed to focusing solely on long novels and poetry—as is often the temptation with Victorian literature—the group will read shorter texts that were widely distributed and widely read at the time of publication, with a particular focus on the short story as an emergent literary genre. We will read works that appeared in publications such as Household Words, Blackwoods, The Morning Chronicle, and Graham’s Magazine , among others. We will, in other words, look to the popular instead of exclusively the canonical and examine how contemporary texts reflected and shaped the dialogue around the issues of the day.      Contact information: Tara Menon                               Contact Us | © New York University , Arts and Science

                Space Priorities        About the Working Group     The University Space Priorities Working Group—first announced at the May 2012 meeting of the University Senate, made up of faculty representatives appointed by the schools and the Faculty Senators Council, as well as representatives from the Student Senators Council and the Administrative Management Council—has been formed to solicit meaningful input from our community. With the zoning envelope now defined, the Working Group will take up the task of giving definitive guidance to the University Administration on implementation; of taking account of the existing, pressing space needs of academic units and programs; and of listening to the implications of the NYU Core Project for members of the University community.
